_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Badger State Ethanol, L.L.C. (BSE), is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for BSE workers, the 

public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, BSE has established a system to help ensure safe 

operation of the processes at this facility.  One component of this system is a Risk Management Program 

(RMP) for anhydrous ammonia that helps manage the risks at BSE and that complies with the requirements of 

the United States Environmental Protection Agency?s (USEPA) regulation 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release 

Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management Program.  



One of the requirements of RMP is to develop a management system to oversee the implementation of the RMP 

elements at BSE.  This document, in conjunction with BSE?s Process Safety Management (PSM) Manual, is 

intended to satisfy the management requirements of RMP.  The following is a summary of BSE?s RMP:



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Program

BSE is committed to the safety of its employees, contractors, visitors, and the surrounding public, and to 

the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous 

substances.  BSE implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  

BSE personnel are trained to respond defensively to releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Their response 

includes the prompt notification of emergency response personnel.  The facility has coordinated 

emergency response procedures with the local fire department and Green County Emergency 

Management.  In the event of a release, which could result in an off-site impact, Green County Emergency 

Management will be contacted to alert the general public.



2.    Badger State Ethanol and the Regulated Substance Handled

The BSE facility in Monroe, Wisconsin, produces fuel-grade ethanol from corn.  The BSE facility has a 

Program 3 covered process due to the on-site storage and use of an

hydrous ammonia.  Anhydrous 

ammonia is used at the facility to control the pH of the slurry tank and to provide nutrients for the yeast 

that is used for fermentation of the grain.  An administrative limit has been implemented to limit the 

maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia in this system to 74,880 pounds.



3.    The General Accidental Release Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

This facility is covered by both the USEPA?s RMP Rule and Occupational Safety and Health 

Administration?s (OSHA) PSM Rule for the anhydrous ammonia process.  This facility implements one 

combined Process Safety and Risk Management Program.  This program consists of a written 

management system.  The backbone of the program is the Management of Change Procedure.  This 

procedure enables the facility to initiate and complete process changes associated with the anhydrous 

ammonia system while maintaining the Process Safety and Risk Management Program requirements at the 

facility.



Both the worst-case and alternative release scenarios were based on equipment failure; therefore, the 

mechanical integrity element of the program is key in preventing releases from the anhydrous ammonia 

process.  This facility utilizes a computerized maintenance management system to implement the 

preventive maintenance, testing, and inspection of the anhydrous ammonia system.  The maintenance 

management system supports the routine preventive maintenance program, which in combination with 

BSE?s employee and contractor training programs provides ongoing assurance that the anhydrous 

ammonia system is operated in a safe manner.



4.    The 5-Year Accident History

This facility began operation on October 22, 2002.  BSE has not experienced an RMP reportable release or 

accident involving anhydrous ammonia in the last 5 years.



5.    The Emergency Response Program

The BSE emergency response program is based on OSHA?s Emergency Action Plan requirements under 

29 CFR 1910.38.  This pr

ogram has been discussed with the local fire departments and has been 

coordinated with Green County Emergency Management.



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

BSE has trained employees on the safety hazards and operation of the anhydrous ammonia process to 

increase safety awareness among their employees.  The facility will continue to make improvements as 

identified by BSE employees, visitors, and contractors.
